text: We could make it go dangerously fast,
but I don't think either of us has the guts
to like plow 45 miles an hour
in a go-kart that's driving itself.
So, we generally have it go like two miles an hour.
I'm Izzy. I'm 17 years old
and I somehow created an autonomous go-kart using AWS DeepRacer.
My first project was a go-kart, a little wood one. I was like four.
My sister and my dad were working on this go-kart
and I’m like, "Okay, that's cool."
Hi, I'm Todd. I'm the dad.
I wanted to make cool things, and have them.
And my dad actually had skills with it.
For a long time he did most of the work, because I was really little.
We started small with making a robot lizard.
Then it was the robotics dragon wings for Halloween.
Then it was a giant cardboard T-Rex costume.
It was insane.
Then the go-kart started.
It was actually my dad who suggested that we make it autonomous.
And I was like, “I agree to it!”, because I’m like,
"How hard could it possibly be?"
That was a year and a half ago.
Once we decided to make it autonomous,
I started coming up with ideas of how that would work,
and then my dad's like,
”Oh, yeah, there's this thing called the DeepRacer.”
It's AWS’s autonomous RC car that we pretty much Frankensteined.
We physically disconnected it from its traditional servos,
hooked it up to bigger servos, to physically control the go-kart.
The DeepLens is the one sensor we use for the DeepRacer.
It's pretty much the eyes of the go-kart.
The DeepLens is taking in visual footage of the track.
It doesn't connect to the internet,
it doesn't do any processing anywhere else,
and then through the magic of machine learning
it turns that into a servo movement to move forward and to turn.
The models are trained in the cloud with SageMaker, RoboMaker.
SageMaker, I think of it like the brain,
it does all the processing, the reasoning.
RoboMaker is the senses — for the DeepRacer, it's the eyes —
and all the processing is in the cloud.
And then we created a model of the environment
we want the go-kart to be able to drive around in.
And that was used over the couple hundred hours
to train the model that then Izzy deployed onto the Red Rover,
and now it drives on the elementary school track down the street.
I’m about to test the go-kart and check the model I’ve been working on,
that is more realistic and matches the go-kart in size.
I guess what pushed me, you know, in the beginning,
was one, “go-karts are cool.”
Two, I just wanted to see if I could.
When I encounter a problem, I refuse to let it beat me.
I kind of see this go-kart as a troublesome child.
I'm like, "We are going to work through this, and it's going to be great,
and you're going to be great," and, you know,
I can't imagine backing down.
